title: Definition of Flyweight Pattern
content: What is the Flyweight Pattern, and why is it useful?
sampleAnswers: It’s a structural design pattern that minimizes memory usage by sharing common object data instead of creating duplicates.
It’s useful when creating a large number of similar objects, e.g., books with the same ISBN.

title: Flyweight Example Output

options.text: Total amount of copies: 5, Total amount of books: 5
Total amount of copies: 3, Total amount of books: 5
Total amount of copies: 5, Total amount of books: 3

title: Advantages of Flyweight Pattern
content: Which of the following are advantages of the Flyweight Pattern?

options.text: Reduced memory usage by reusing objects

title: Disadvantages of Flyweight Pattern
content: What is a drawback of using the Flyweight Pattern?
sampleAnswers: It can increase code complexity by adding an extra layer of object management.
Modern hardware often has enough memory, so the benefit may be negligible in many applications.

title: Flyweight vs Factory Pattern
content: How does the Flyweight Pattern differ from the Factory Pattern?
sampleAnswers: Factory Pattern abstracts object creation, while Flyweight Pattern focuses on sharing existing objects to save memory.
Factory decides *how* to create, Flyweight decides *whether to reuse*.

title: Fix the Bug
sampleAnswers: The code incorrectly treats `isbnNumbers.has(isbn)` as the book object, but it returns a boolean.
A `Map` or dictionary should be used to store ISBN → Book mappings, not just a `Set`.

title: When to Use Flyweight
content: In which situation would the Flyweight Pattern be the best choice?

options.text: When creating thousands of objects that share common properties
When creating a single instance of a service
When setting up event delegation in DOM

title: Flyweight Pattern in Modern JS
content: Why is the Flyweight Pattern considered less critical in modern JavaScript applications compared to older times?
sampleAnswers: Because modern devices have large amounts of memory (RAM), so optimizing object count is less often necessary.
JavaScript engines also optimize memory allocation internally.
